he denies ignoring rules and controlling the trust in question .

senator bernie sanders , who lost out to hilary clinton in the race to be the democratic presidential nominee in the last us election , has attacked the billionaires and corporations exposed by the paradise papers .
he told the guardian : the major issue of our time is the rapid movement toward international oligarchy in which a handful of billionaires own and control a significant part of the global economy .
the paradise papers shows how these billionaires and multinational corporations get richer by hiding their wealth and profits and avoid paying their fair share of taxes .
this is a major problem not just for the united states but for governments throughout the world .

in congress , instead of providing even more tax breaks to profitable corporations like apple and nike and billionaires in trump 's cabinet who avoid billions in us taxes by shifting american jobs and profits to offshore tax havens , we need to close these loopholes and demand a fair and progressive tax system .
i applaud the journalists who uncovered this tax scam .

before congress considers tax legislation , it must fully investigate the paradise papers to make sure that the billionaire class can no longer stash their cash in the cayman islands , bermuda and other offshore tax havens .

labour 's clive efford asks how an average taxpayer in eltham , which he represents , can benefit from offshore trusts in the same ways that the eye-wateringly rich do .
stride says the opposition 's characterisation of people using such trusts as all being eye-wateringly rich and/or tax dodgers is inaccurate .
and that concludes the urgent question .
stride is asked why people saving for their children 's future would need to make use of accounts in the likes of bermuda .
he refuses to answer , saying that is not what he said .
labour 's david hanson asks stride what he thinks about non-doms donating to political parties in the uk .
stride says the government has put an end to permanent non-dom status .
stride says the wealthiest 1 % in the country pay 28 % of all income tax whereas the figure was 23 % under labour .
the dup 's jim shannon suggests reminding companies of their moral obligation to pay a fair amount of tax .
stride says they will be pursued by hmrc where they have not done so .
labour 's david lammy asks stride to expand on the the legitimate reasons he claimed there could be for a trust .
stride says there are many reasons including a trust for children that the parents want kept secret .
the financial secretary to the treasury says the government has taken/is taking 35 additional measures before the end of the parliament to clamp down on tax avoidance .
conservative mp kelly tolhurst claims labour had 13 years and did nothing .
labour 's jack dromey says it is obscene that rich people should seek to get even richer through use of trusts while working people have seen a prolonged stagnation of wages .
stride says he 'll take no lectures from labour .
labour 's stella creasy asks if the government will commit to a moratorium on companies being investigated being awarded public sector contracts .
stride says he is not going to go down the path of moratoriums , although he says it is tempting .
labour 's luciana berger asks how many more panorama programmes and leaks will be required before action is taken .
stride says the government has brought in â£ 160bn in tax avoidance since 2010 ( a figure he has highlighted at least three times ) .
labour 's liam byrne says there should be transparency in all trade treaties .
stride says the government is committed to country-by-country reporting .
labour 's dennis skinner says the government is more concerned with hounding disabled people than focusing on the real people dodging tax , people who are close to the conservative party .
stride argues the tories have a far stronger record on tax avoidance than labour .
the green party 's caroline lucas says the government should drop its morally indefensible opposition to an eu blacklist of tax havens .
stride says lucas is incorrect and the government has done nothing to block such a blacklist .
stride says the tax gap is at a historic low of 6 % whereas it was 8 % under labour , a difference of â£ 11.2bn .
labour 's margaret hodge says there needs to be openness about who owns which company where and who owns which trust .
hodge asks why the government will not insist that british territories have to have a public register .
stride says there are decent reasons why people use offshore trusts .
labour 's angela eagle asks about the tangled involvement of russian money .
she too urges the government to create a register .
stride says there are registers accessible to hmrc in overseas territories ( although these are not open to the public ) .
he says hmrc will no doubt look into any involvement of russian money .
stride refuses to discuss ashcroft but he says the tories have put an end to non-dom status .
peter bone , tory mp for wellingborough , says people are only upset about morally wrong avoidance , which he accuses labour of , saying the party 's hq is owned by an overseas trust .
the snp 's stewart hosie says the revelations offer no hiding place for those who would deny creation of a register of trusts and beneficial interests .
stride says the government has been at the forefront of clamping down on international tax avoidance .
stride says there are legitimate reasons for such tax arrangements , calling labour 's accusations general .
mcdonnell says it is unacceptable that the chancellor is not there to answer questions on the biggest tax scandal of this generation .
he asks stride about the domicile status of lord ashcroft between 2010 and 2015 and whether he was paying the full amount of tax during that time .
responding to john mcdonnell 's urgent question , mel stride , financial secretary to the treasury , says : this government believes in a fair tax system .
on 25 october , hmrc requested that the media organisations share the data that is the subject of the paradise papers but they have not responded to this request , says stride .
labour leader jeremy corbyn has said the queen 's tax affairs should be subject to the inquiry his party has called for into tax avoidance , in the wake of the paradise papers revelations .
in an interview with bloomberg tv , he said : there should be a review .
an inquiry into all the revelations about the paradise papers .
asked if that included the queen , corbyn replied : everybody .
the royal household are subject to taxation .
i do n't know what has happened in that case .
these issues all must be part of that .
speaking at the cbi conference earlier today , corbyn was asked if the queen should apologise for the â£ 7.5m investment in a cayman islands fund as part of an offshore portfolio .

he replied : anyone putting money into tax havens in order to avoid taxation in britain and obviously investigations have to take place should do two things : not just apologise for it but also recognise what it does to our society .
later , a spokesman for corbyn said he did not call for the queen to apologise and said his comments were aimed more broadly .
[ he ] said anyone who puts money into a tax haven to avoid paying tax should , and that they should recognise the damage done by avoidance to society .
coming up shortly , at approximately 3.30pm , the shadow chancellor , john mcdonnell , will be asking an urgent question about the paradise papers in parliament .
the former chancellor george osborne has used his new role as editor of the evening standard to defend the record of the government he was part of on tackling tax avoidance .
in an editorial on the issue the paper says the queen 's advisers should probably have steered clear of cayman islands investments , if only for appearances ' sake .
but it adds : you can not any longer easily hide your money from the taxman in an offshore bank account .

that is because at the g8 in 2013 , britain led the way in getting 90 countries including the jerseys and cayman islands of this world to agree to share automatically the details of these bank accounts with the relevant tax authorities .

britain has also been at the forefront in europe of ensuring that information on who ultimately owns companies and trusts is internationally available to tax and law enforcement agencies ; and it is important that pressure is maintained to make that too a global standard .
yes , people rich and otherwise break the law and do n't pay the taxes that are due .
but the weapons available to those trying to catch them are much more powerful than they used to be .
we should not equate anyone who has financial investments overseas with criminals .
if we do , then , rather than lamenting the collapse of trust in the institutions and rules that secure our freedom we will be contributing to that collapse .

len mccluskey fuller/pa britain 's biggest union has backed labour 's call for a public inquiry into tax avoidance .

unite 's general secretary , len mccluskey , said : taxpayers will be furious at the efforts of the super-rich and their advisers , including the queen 's , go to dodge paying their fair share of tax .
these tax avoidance schemes may be legal , but there is deep anger and disgust about the them and us ' attitude to paying tax revealed in the paradise papers ' .

the prime minister 's refusal this morning to commit to introducing a public register of who owns offshore companies and trusts in british tax havens or to opening a public inquiry into tax avoidance is to be strongly deplored .
the government should refuse public contracts to tax avoiders it is the government 's duty to use public money responsibly , and lining the pockets of tax dodgers is not doing so .
the tax avoidance industry that secretes the billions of the tax dodging elite needs to be outlawed .
tax avoidance is as immoral as tax evasion .
if you want to trade , work or live in the uk , then the message is simple pay your proper share of taxes .

this is a global problem that needs concerted international action , but there is nothing to stop theresa may 's government taking the lead on this with robust proposals and the budget on 22 november would be a good place to start .
junior minister sam gyimah , a former cbi entrepreneur of the future , claims the government should be proud of its record on tackling tax avoidance .
writing on facebook he lists five things the government has done to clamp down on the problem .
top of the list is requiring tax havens , like bermuda , to agree to give the police access to hidden accounts .
he does n't mention the uk 's resistance to calls to make such information fully transparent .

the bermuda flag gunther/epa the anti-corruption campaign global witness has accused bermuda 's leader of misleading bbc listeners by suggesting that the island 's register of companies was open to the public .
david burt , the premier of bermuda , told bbc radio 4 's today programme , that his government 's register of ownership was not secret .

bermuda has known who the beneficial owners of our companies have been for 70 years , that is far in excess of many countries around the world , including the united kingdom and the united states ( see earlier ) .
murray worhty , senior campaigner at global witness , said burt was being disingenuous .

he said : the premier of bermuda was really misleading listeners on the today programme who could understandably think that bermuda does have public access to the true owners of companies based there .
this is not true .
bermuda does not have a public register of the owners of companies based there and has in fact lobbied the uk government heavily to prevent such measures from being introduced .
speaking on the bbc 's world at one programme , worthy said the uk government had a unique responsibility to tackle tax havens .
he said : bermuda is one of the uk 's overseas territories , one of the uk 's overseas tax havens essentially .
these are at the heart of these paradise papers , these hidden anonymous companies enabling tax avoidance , tax evasion .
so it 's vital that we get to know who is behind these companies and the best way to do that is through making that ownership information public .
the uk agreed with territories like bermuda for the police to have access to some of this information , however that really does n't go far enough .

in the cases we 've looked at , we 've seen anonymous companies in the uk 's tax havens being used in corruption , money laundering , bribery schemes linked to many of the world 's poorest countries .
those very poorly resourced countries have no way of accessing this information .
those countries that need it most are n't able to get it .
the uk has a really unique role in this offshore system and therefore has a unique responsibility for cleaning it up .

the queen 's investment in brighthouse , the controversial hire purchase retailer , will undermine public loyalty to the monarchy , according to one customer who claims the firm tried to charge her â£ 2,700 for a sofa worth about â£ 800 .
the duchy of lancaster , which manages the queen 's private estate , invested in brighthouse in 2005 via a cayman islands fund , according to the paradise papers investigation .
last month the financial conduct authority found brighthouse had not been a responsible lender and ordered it to repay â£ 14.8m to 249,000 customers .
the queen 's holding is now small at â£ 3,208 , but the duchy invested when the company was worth significantly more .
it is not known what profit or loss it has made from the holding .
this is shocking , said laura hutchison , 31 , a mother living on benefits in galston , scotland .
i thought she would invest in charities .
when you see what she is doing how do you expect us to look up to her and be loyal .
i used to look up to her and be patriotic .
hutchinson said brighthouse repeatedly threatened to repossess a sofa she bought when pregnant and lacking funds because she missed some repayments .
she said she spent about â£ 800 but could not afford to continue and it was finally repossessed , even though it was only worth around â£ 800 .
her view was echoed by dame margaret hodge , former chairwoman of the commons public accounts committee , who said the investment sullies [ the queen 's ] reputation .
that is tragic , she said .
it comes from a mix of what is considered acceptable now and the secrecy with which these accounts are administered .
the queen is going to survive this , but it is undoubtedly damaging .
frank field mp , the chairman of the commons work and pensions committee said the queen 's advisers had totally failed in their duty to protect the poor and the queen .

he said : that this money was allowed to flow offshore and then into a company that has behaved so wickedly towards the poor behaviour which has left some parents unable to afford meals or clothing for their children should pose some tough questions to those who were on the duchy council at the time of the decision and have since offered such inadequate oversight of the queen 's investments .
the duchy of lancaster manages over â£ 500m but its chief finance officer , chris adcock , told the guardian it had been unaware of its indirect holding in brighthouse .
investors commit to a fund for a given period and are not party to its ongoing investment decisions , he said .

this is a classic example of the elite in great britain having absolutely no idea about what happens to the poor of great britain , said rev paul nicolson , director of the taxpayers against poverty campaign .
someone needs to go along to the queen with someone on a zero-hours contract who has had their benefit stopped for three months and has the bailiffs come along .
someone needs to teach the queen about what is happening .

in a statement , brighthouse said : we are appreciated by our customers , because we help those financially excluded on the basis of low incomes and poor credit histories to get everyday items they otherwise could n't have .

documents.title: corbyn suggests the queen should apologise
text: jeremy corbyn has suggested the queen should apologise after the paradise papers revealed that some of her wealth has been invested offshore .

asked whether the monarch should say sorry over the revelations , corbyn said : anyone that is putting money into tax havens in order to avoid taxation in britain , and obviously investigations have to take place , should do two things : not just apologise for it but also recognise what it does to our society , because if a very wealthy person wants to avoid taxation in britain and therefore put money into a tax haven somewhere , who loses ?

schools , hospitals , housing , all those public services lose and the rest of the population have to pay to cover up the deficit created by that we simply have to challenge the culture that there is something clever about avoiding taxation .
taxation is what gives us ambulances , gives us fire tenders , gives us safety in our lives and we all have a responsibility to pay for it .
we are undermined by this kind of evasion .
it must stop .

documents.title: corbyn calls for end to 'extortionately costly scandal '
text: labour leader jeremy corbyn has spoken of his determination to end the tax evasion on an industrial scale revealed in the paradise papers .
speaking at the cbi conference he said labour was considering a withholding tax on those abusing the system .
he said : the shocking revelations from the paradise papers today , yet again of widespread tax avoidance and evasion on an industrial scale must lead to decisive action and real change .
it is by no means all big businesses but these actions by a few undermine trust in all businesses .
and businesses are the victim too , not just reputationally but financially .
those businesses that play by the rules and pay the taxes they owe are being undercut by those who do n't .
the vital revenues government needs to fund an industrial strategy , good infrastructure and the world class education system we aspire to ; these things can only be delivered by fair taxation .

so while we must n't tarnish all businesses by the actions of the few , we also have a duty to come down hard on those who are avoiding the responsibilities and give hm revenue & customs the resources it needs .

as our shadow chancellor john mcdonnell has set out this morning , we need a full public inquiry into tax avoidance and evasion , on and offshore , a register of companies and trusts , and who benefits from them , and a new tax enforcement unit in hmrc and an end to public contracts for companies abusing the system .
and we will look at using a withholding tax where individuals or companies are involved in abusing the system and end public contracts for companies engaged in abusive tax avoidance .
please understand the public anger and consternation at the scale of tax avoidance revealed yet again today .
we are talking about tens of billions that are effectively being leached from our vital public services by a super-rich elite that holds the taxation system and the rest of us in contempt .
we must take action now to put an end to this socially damaging and extortionately costly scandal .

tax justice uk has called on theresa may to clamp down on tax avoidance in the wake of the paradise papers leaks.will snell , director of tax justice uk , said : the government knows what needs to be done to tackle tax avoidance and evasion , but the issue just has n't been a priority .
in fact , rather than take on the tax dodgers , successive governments have cut off hmrc at its knees , slashing its funding and the number of tax inspectors by half over the last decade .

when the wealthy engage in the kind of practices seen in the paradise papers , they are the pockets of nurses , teachers , doctors and other hard-working public servants , and harming the lives of everyone in the uk who uses public services .
the latest leak of information from one of the largest facilitators of the offshore system shows that the tax avoidance industry is still alive and well .
the government must now take swift action to make sure that tax dodgers are brought to heel .

it is therefore not surprising that in the eu , the british government has slowed the fight against tax evasion and money laundering for years and is now opposed to development of a credible european blacklist of tax havens .
the eu must be firm in the brexit negotiations : no access to the european single market for the uk if it continues to act as a tax haven on our doorstep .
in a statement joly added : the paradise papers highlight the whole professionalisation of the global system of tax evasion .
if all this is legal ' then it is necessary to change the laws .

with political will , the european union , as the world 's largest market , has the means to tackle tax evasion .
the means to isolate the recalcitrant countries these reforms are currently being discussed at european level but are still blocking at member state level .

documents.title: wilbur ross denies misleading congress
text: donald trump 's commerce secretary , wilbur ross , has denied misleading congress , after the paradise papers leak exposed details of his interests in a company doing business with a russian firm controlled by members of vladimir putin 's inner circle .

pa reports : ross said it was totally incorrect to claim that he withheld details of his involvement with shipping firm navigator when disclosing his financial affairs to a senate committee earlier this year .

among a cache of documents leaked from a bermuda-based law firm are papers showing that the billionaire industrialist retains an interest in navigator holdings , one of whose most important business relationships is with energy firm sibur .
sibur is controlled by figures close to putin , including the russian president 's son-in-law .
democratic senator richard blumenthal has called for an investigation into mr ross , claiming he misled the senate commerce committee during confirmation hearings in january .

but ross said blumenthal 's comments were totally incorrect , as his holding in navigator was disclosed in three separate points in his disclosure form lodged with the us office of government ethics .

he said he played no part in the negotiation of a deal by sibur to charter ships from navigator and had never met shareholders in the russian company who are the subject of us sanctions in response to moscow 's interference in ukraine .
ross told reporters during a trade visit to london it would be incorrect to characterise navigator 's relationship with sibur as a partnership of any kind .
he said : navigator charters out vessels and one of its charter customers a big charter customer happens to be sibur..
the negotiations to buy these vessels and the negotiations to charter the vessels to sibur were done before i became a director of navigator .

the most important point is that sibur was not sanctioned at the time that navigator did the deal nor is it under sanctions right now , so there is no sanction prohibition against any of the dealings with sibur .
the fact that they had some shareholders who had been sanctioned really does n't tell you very much .
i have never met either of those shareholders , do not know them and had no role in negotiating the transaction between sibur and navigator .
this would have been something not good had it not been disclosed , but it has been quite fulsomely disclosed .
navigator was not a security i was requested by the oge to divest of we have complied with all aspects of the oge ruling .

the leak of millions of records from companies who specialise in offshore banking services has sparked a sensation in india amid a highly publicised crackdown on untaxed wealth what the narendra modi government labels black money .

more than 700 indians appeared in the records accessed by news organisations including some of the country 's best-known actors and several members of the main opposition congress and ruling bharatiya janata party ( bjp ) .
jayanta sinha , india 's minister of state for aviation , is the highest ranking politician to appear .
according to the indian express , while working for an investment fund sinha served as the director of a solar company with a subsidiary in the cayman islands .

text: let 's recap on the developments so far .
the guardian , along with almost 100 media partners , have today revealed the paradise papers , a vast cache of 13.4m documents , one of the largest leaks ever seen .
the majority of the files come from appleby , an offshore law firm specialising in the world 's tax havens .
the documents expose the secrets and financial affairs of some of the world 's most powerful and wealthy .
the most significant revelations made so far include : the queen 's private estate invested millions of pounds in a cayman islands fund .
some of her money went to a retailer accused of exploiting poor families and vulnerable people .

links between trump 's commerce secretary , wilbur ross , and the son-in-law of vladimir putin , through ross 's investment in a shipping group , navigator russian state financial institutions have been linked with hundreds of millions of dollars in investments in twitter and facebook .
canadian prime minister justin trudeau 's chief fundraiser was involved in the movement of millions of dollars to offshore havens .

a range of groups have called for multinational companies to disclose their tax affairs on a country-by-country basis .
this would force transparency and help prevent the shifting of profits to low-tax jurisdictions .
the former united nations secretary general kofi annan said transparency was the only way to stop large companies looting african nations .
the tax justice network called for the united nations to convene a summit of world leaders to find a way to end tax abuse and financial secrecy .
transparency international wants greater transparency on the beneficial ownership of corporations , to prevent them using use complex and hidden structures to mask their true owners .
it also wants measures to compel law firms and other intermediaries to report sus of money laundering .
labour leader jeremy corbyn said the paradise papers are further evidence that there 's one rule for the super-rich and another for the rest of us .

it 's easy to lose sight of the human consequences of tax avoidance .
the point has been made this morning by oxfam and transparency international that denying tax revenue to government takes away crucial funding for essential services , like hospitals or schools .
but just how much revenue are governments across the globe losing to tax avoidance ?
the latest estimate from the tax justice network suggests profit shifting has exploded in the past decade .
the network says governments are losing $ 500bn a year in taxes due to avoidance by big multinationals .
that represents over 20 % of corporate tax revenues .
researchers at the international monetary fund found tax haven spillovers were causing tax losses of $ 400bn for oecd members per year , and $ 200bn for lower-income countries .

the chief executive officer , alex cobham , said it was not enough to simply respond to individual companies or jurisdictions doing the wrong thing .
instead , world leaders needed to address the fundamental and systemic aspects of global finance , which were allowing tax to be avoided with impunity .
cobham said world leaders needed to agree a path to ending financial secrecy and tax abuse for good .
binding targets to reduce illicit financial flows ought to be developed , he said , alongside accountability measures to ensure progress was made .
multinationals should be forced to report their tax affairs country by country , to ensure profits were not being shifted to low-tax jurisdictions .
these leaks confirm the systemic nature of tax abuse and corrupt practices , with global financial secrecy being marketed by major law firms , banks and accounting firms , cobham said .

documents.title: australia 's politicians react to the paradise papers
text: in australia the resources minister , matthew canavan , has been quizzed about revelations that glencore , a swiss-based mining giant , used cross-currency swaps of up to $ 25bn of a type under specific investigation by the australian tax office .
canavan would n't comment on the detail of glencore 's affairs .
but he said the australian government was committed to stamping out tax avoidance more generally .

you might have seen that recently the australian tax office did take a very large case involving chevron , which it was successful with , but that is still subject to appeal , canavan told the australian broadcasting corporation .
the australian government is taking these issues very seriously , it is absolutely the case that companies operating here , making profits here , must pay tax here , he said .
my colleague in australia , gareth hutchens , has been listening to the reaction of treasurer scott morrison to the paradise papers .
morrison said the australian tax office has been on the job and proactive in stopping multinational tax avoidance .

he dismissed the labor opposition 's calls for comprehensive country-by-country tax data to be publicly released , saying companies would refuse to share their information with tax officials if they knew the information would be released publicly .
if you were to go down labor 's path the information would turn off .
it would just turn off , he said .
i think it shows extreme naivety on behalf of the labor party in not understanding how the base erosion and profit-shifting processes work .
i 'm not going to do anything that 's going to undermine a key information tool that is actually helping tax jurisdictions to put an end to these sort of tax-shifting arrangements , he said .
new laws on multinational corporate tax avoidance were introduced in australia in 2015 by the coalition .

the tax office has recently netted an additional $ 4bn in tax revenue from multinationals , but labor 's shadow assistant treasurer , andrew leigh , has previously said that has little to do with the new laws .
leigh issued a statement following the paradise papers publication , calling on prime minister malcolm turnbull to commit to greater tax transparency in australia .

we take any allegation of wrongdoing , implicit or otherwise , extremely seriously .

we are also committed to the highest standards of client service and confidentiality .
it is what we stand for .
this commitment is unequivocal .
appleby has thoroughly and vigorously investigated the allegations and we are satisfied that there is no evidence of any wrongdoing , either on the part of ourselves or our clients .

we refute any allegations that may suggest otherwise and we would be happy to cooperate fully with any legitimate and authorised investigation of the allegations by the appropriate and relevant authorities .
we are an offshore law firm that advises clients on legitimate and lawful ways to conduct their business .
we do not tolerate illegal behaviour .
it is true that we are not infallible .
